items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourn area have been declining slowly due to the limited rainfall over the last few weeks. Groundwater levels are still above normal for this time of year, and are still high and close to a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater if we receive heavy rainfall.

We expect groundwater levels to remain high over the next week but they are continuing to fall slowly. The groundwater levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. Low-lying land and roads therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message Tuesday 30/03/2021, or as the situation changes.

Groundwater levels have responded to high autumn and winter rainfall and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Ashley Green, Chesham.

Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in Chesham such as the Vale Road area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater.  

We expect levels to remain high over the coming weeks in response to the high winter rainfall. Low lying lands and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding.   

Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.  We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 31st March or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Burn from Southgate and Waterden to Burnham Thorpe
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is still likely today, Monday 22nd March, and into next week.  River and groundwater levels remain high and are expected to remain high for the next few weeks.  The forecast is for dry conditions today.  Take care on riverside footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.  We are monitoring the situation and levels closely, and will update this message by 10am, Monday 29th March.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high autumn and winter rainfall, and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom.     
Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom areas are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater.  
We expect levels to remain high over the coming weeks in response to the high winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads will therefore be at risk of groundwater flooding.   
Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 31st March or as the situation changes.

Groundwater levels have responded to high autumn and winter rainfall, and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill close to Flamstead.

Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater.  

We expect levels to remain high over the coming weeks in response to the high winter rainfall. Low lying land and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of groundwater flooding.   

Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 31st March or as the situation changes.

Groundwater levels at the Snailwell Borehole are steady but remain high. Consequently there is an increased risk of groundwater flooding. We expect flooding to affect areas of Newmarket at risk of groundwater flooding, including the High Street. There is potential for further rainfall this week, therefore there is a risk that the groundwater levels will remain high over the next few weeks. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water. This message is updated weekly due to the slow reaction and will be updated Wednesday 31 March, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Little Stour, Nailbourne, River Wingham, River Stour

items.message: The Nailbourne & Little Stour have been flowing since mid-January. Levels peaked in February and are now slowly in recession. However, some flooding of low-lying land, gardens and roads is still occurring at various locations including North Elham, Barham, Patrixbourne, Bridge and Littlebourne. Some roads remain closed at fording points. The internal flooding of residential properties is not expected. The Littlebourne Flood Relief Channel is in operation and temporary defences operate in Barham. Please avoid driving in floodwater as bow waves from vehicles may cause property flooding. Environment Agency operatives are ensuring the free flow of water. We are monitoring the situation and co-ordinating efforts with local authorities and community leaders. Levels are gradually reducing but this alert will remain in force until more roads are opened to traffic. This message will be updated by Friday 2 April or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but steady at the Marham and Setchey Bridge river gauges. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland remains possible. We expect flooding to affect the River Nar from Litcham to South Lynn. No rainfall is forecast over the next few days, however we expect the river levels to remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Monday 29 March, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message:
Groundwater levels at our observation borehole at Northfield Farm in the Great Shefford area are slowly falling due to limited rainfall over the last few weeks. Groundwater levels are still above normal for this time of year, and are still high and close to a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater if we receive heavy rainfall. 

We expect levels to remain high, but continue to fall slowly over the next week. Water levels remain sensitive to further rainfall and could start to rise again in response to rainfall. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message Tuesday (30/03/2021), or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Mint Bridge and Victoria Bridge river gauges as a result of recent rainfall. With further heavy rainfall continuing throughout the night, river levels are expected to remain high into tomorrow morning 29/03/21.  We are not currently expecting to issue any Flood Warnings. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible.   Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Staveley, Ings, Burneside, Kendal, Garnett Bridge, Stainton, Sedgwick, Holme, Beetham and Milnthorpe areas. High river levels are possible on the Rivers Kent, Gowan, Sprint, Mint, Stock Beck, Stainton Beck, Peasey Beck, Farleton Beck, River Bela, Holme Beck and their tributaries.   We are closely monitoring the situation.   This message will be updated tomorrow 29/03/21 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
Derwent Water Lake level is forecast to rise as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible.  Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Seatoller, Stonethwaite, Rosthwaite, Grange-in-Borrowdale and Derwent Water shoreline areas. High river and lake levels are possible on the River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck, Watendlath Beck, Derwent Water and their tributaries.    

We expect lake levels to remain high over the coming days due to further rainfall forecast. 

We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences.   

Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers and lakeside.   

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 29/03/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brathay, River Rothay, River Winster

items.message: River levels have risen at the Far Sawrey gauge as a result of overnight rainfall and todays showers.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. With further heavy rainfall tonight, River levels are expected to remain high into tomorrow morning 29/03/21. We are not currently expecting to issue any Flood Warnings. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Langdale, Grasmere, Ambleside, Troutbeck, Windermere, Hawkshead, Rusland Valley, Newby Bridge, Backbarrow, Cartmel, Cark and Winster Valley areas. High river and lake levels are possible on Great Langdale Beck, River Brathay, River Rothay, Trout Beck, Mill Beck, Cunsey Beck, Windermere Lake, Rusland Pool, River Eea, River Winster and their tributaries.  We are closely monitoring the situation.   This message will be updated tomorrow 29/03/21 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Calder, Walsden Water, Hebden Water

items.message:
River levels in the upper River Calder are rising again due to a further area of heavy rainfall affecting the area this evening, Sunday 28th March. We currently expect levels in Walsden and Todmorden area to peak around midnight, before dropping again later tonight as the rain becomes less heavy. This second peak in river levels is likely to be higher than the one this morning, but we do not anticipate issuing flood warnings as a result of this rainfall. There may be localized surface water issues where the heaviest rainfall occurs. 

We are monitoring the situation closely and have operational staff ready to check key locations. Please do not put yourself at risk by walking or driving through flood water. For the latest flood warning and river level information, visit our flood warning information service at www.gov.uk

This message will be updated by 08:00 on 29/03/21, or as the situation changes. We anticipate removing this flood alert on Monday morning.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater remains high.  Over the last 7 days, there has been a slight increase in level in Appleshaw and Hatherden, as groundwater responded to rain which was recorded between 10th and 13th March. In Kimpton, the level continues to fall. From today (Wednesday 24/03/21) until next week, small amounts of rain are forecast, with heavy showers expected on Friday (26/03/21). In Hatherden and Appleshaw, groundwater has not yet lowered for a period of several successive days.  Rain this week could therefore cause levels to rise (perhaps by another 10 cm or so). Whilst it is unlikely that rain this week will cause impacts, groundwater is only marginally below a level where historically, a small  number of cellars have been affected in Hatherden and Appleshaw. We would therefore like communities to remain prepared, just over the next few weeks. We will update this message by 12:00 on Wednesday 31st March 2021.

River levels have risen at the Bampton Grange river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Bampton, Patterdale, Glenridding, Dockray, Pooley Bridge, Dacre, Eamont Bridge and Penrith areas. High river and lake levels are possible on the River Lowther, Haweswater Beck, Goldrill Beck, Grisedale Beck, Glenridding Beck, Aira Beck, Ullswater, River Eamont, Dacre Beck, Thacka Beck and their tributaries.    

We expect river levels to remain high until Tuesday 30/03/21 as further rain is forecast.  

We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences.   

Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.   

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 29/03/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Swale, Gilling Beck, Skeeby Beck

items.message: The Flood Alert for the Upper Swale remains in force.  River levels in the upper catchment are rising again in response to this evenings rainfall. River levels in the Reeth and Grinton Bridge areas could reach levels that may cause localised flooding, between 10pm this evening and 6am tomorrow, Monday 29th March. Consequently, flooding of low lying roads and farmland remains possible.  Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff continue to closely monitor the forecast.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated on Monday morning, or as the situation changes.

Lake levels are rising at the Lodore gauge as a result of persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible.  With further rainfall expected overnight, levels will remain high into tomorrow 29/03/21.  The peak is expected in the early hours at approximately 2.3m.  Flooding is expected to affect low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near rivers and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow, 29/03/2021, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Swale, Cod Beck, Bedale Beck

items.message: The Flood Alert for the Lower Swale remains in force as river levels are rising at both Maunby, and Crakehill, in response to recent heavy rain. It is possible that river levels may fall temporarily overnight – but will rise again by tomorrow morning in response to this evenings rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland remains possible.  Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff continue to closely monitoring the forecast.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated on Monday morning, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ure at Roecliffe Caravan Park
items.message: The flood warning for the River Ure at Roecliffe Caravan Park has been issued due to rising river levels following recent heavy rainfall. The river level at Westwick Lock is currently 1.5m and is forecast to rise steadily, peaking at approximately 1.8m tomorrow morning, Monday 29th March. Consequently, flooding is expected/possible tonight and tomorrow morning in the Roecliffe Caravan Park area.  Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated on Monday morning, 29th March, or as the situation changes.

River levels have peaked at the Stockdalewath and Cummersdale river gauges but will remain high throughout the day.  The river levels are expected to rise again from 21:00 due to heavy showers expected later on this evening and overnight.  At this time we do not expect it to reach flood warning. Consequently, flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in the Millhouse, Caldbeck, Sebergham, Ivegill, Stockdalewath, Dalston, Cummersdale, Denton Holme, Greystoke, Plumpton, Upperby and Harraby Green areas. High river levels are possible on the River Caldew, Cald Beck, River Ive, River Roe, North Petteril, River Petteril and their tributaries. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers. This message will be updated tomorrow, 29/03/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels have peaked upstream at Kirkby Stephen and the levels are forecast to peak around midday at the Appleby river gauge. The levels are expected to fall until into the evening but with heavy rain expected over night the levels will begin to rise again from around 21:00 28/3/21.  We are not currently expecting the level to reach Flood Warning or impact the Sands area at this time.  The risk of flooding of low lying land and roads remains. Flooding is expected to affect low lying areas in the Ravenstonedale, Kirkby Stephen, Brough, Warcop, Great Asby, Great Ormside, Appleby-in-Westmorland, Bolton, Crosby Ravensworth and Morland areas. High river levels are possible on the River Eden, Scandal Beck, Swindale Beck, Crooks Beck, Asby Beck, River Lyvennet, Morland Beck and their tributaries. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers. This message will be updated tomorrow, 29/03/21, or as the situation changes.

Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated on Monday morning, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: The flood alert for North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea remains in force. Overtopping waves and spray are expected as a result of high astronomical tides tomorrow, Monday 29th March, between 18:30 and 20:00.  Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast.  Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  This message will be updated on Monday morning, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall
items.message: The flood alert for Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall remains in force. Overtopping waves and spray are expected as a result of high astronomical tides tomorrow, Monday 29th March, between 17:30 and 19:00.  Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast.  Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads, as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.  This message will be updated on Monday morning, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise again as a result of persistent rainfall through this evening, Sunday 28th March. Consequently, flooding of low lying roads and farmland is possible from Sunday evening (28/03/2021) into the early hours of Monday morning (29/03/2021).  Areas most at risk are Skipton Washlands, Snaygill Ings, and Cononley Washlands.    
We currently expect river levels to begin rising at around 8pm this evening and to peak between 3 and 5a.m on Monday morning .
We expect Cononley Washlands to start filling through the early hours of Monday morning but the rainfall should move away overnight, allowing levels to drop on the River Aire during Monday.
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 07:30 on 29/03/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: The Flood Alert for the Tidal River Ouse has been issued as river levels are expected to rise overnight into Monday morning, 29th March following recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of low lying footpaths,  roads and farmland is possible.  Our incident response staff continue to closely monitoring the forecast.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated on Monday  morning, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Eden at Carlisle, Rickerby Park, Swifts and Stoneyholme Golf Courses
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Linstock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected. Flooding is expected to affect low lying roads, car parks, public spaces and recreational facilities at Rickerby Park, Swifts and Stoneyholme Golf Courses.   
We expect river levels to remain high during today 29/03/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow morning, 30/03/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Monday morning. High water at Ilfracombe is at 7.15am, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Strong force 6 south westerly winds and offshore wave heights of over 2.7m are forecast to cause wave overtopping of sea defences and sea spray in exposed coastal locations.  Expect tides to be around 140mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.
People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.
Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.
Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe is 5.10 mAOD, this is 0.14 metres above astronomical tide level.

River levels on local becks in Earby and Glusburn area are rising again due to a further area of heavy rainfall affecting these areas this evening, Sunday 28th March. We currently expect levels on Earby Beck, Earby New Cut and Glusburn Beck to peak between 11pm this evening and 1a.m Monday morning, before dropping again later tonight as the rain becomes less heavy. This second peak in river levels is likely to be higher than the one this morning, but we do not anticipate issuing flood warnings as a result of this rainfall. There may be localized surface water issues where the heaviest rainfall occurs. 

Please do not put yourself at risk by walking or driving through flood water. For the latest flood warning and river level information, visit our flood warning information service at www.gov.uk

This message will be updated by 08:00 on 29/03/21, or as the situation changes. We anticipate removing this flood alert on Monday morning.

The Flood Alert for the Upper Ure remains in force. River levels in the Upper Ure catchment are expected to rise again in response to this evenings rainfall.  The River Ure at Kilgram is expected to rise and reach around 4m in the early hours of tomorrow morning (Monday 29th March) in response to this evenings rain.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. Our incident response staff continue to closely monitor the forecast.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  This message will be updated on Monday morning, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Caton river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 28/03/2021 through to tomorrow 29/03/2021 . Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads from Kirkby Lonsdale to Conder Green including Ingleton, High and Low Bentham, Wray, Hornby, Carnforth, Caton, Halton, Lancaster, Scotforth and Galgate. High river levels are possible on the Rivers Greta, Wenning, Hindburn, Roeburn, Keer, Lune, Conder, Burrow Beck and their tributaries. We expect river levels to remain high , expecting it to peak at 06:00 tomorrow, 29/03/2021. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near rivers.

items.description: South Cornwall Coast from Lizard Point to Gribbin Head excluding Truro City
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the morning high tide on Monday 29th March.  


Offshore wave heights of approximately 1.7 metres are forecast, together with Force 5 south westerly winds.  


Spray and overtopping may impact on coastal structures as well as wave run-up at slipways and beaches. It may cause minor flooding of quaysides and low-lying land and roads.  Be prepared to take action with individual property protection measures. 


High water at Truro is at 06:45 on Monday; times of high water will vary along the coast.  Peak tide level may be up to 100mm lower than published. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of high tide. Locations which may be affected include Flushing, Penryn, St.Mawes, Calenick, Mevagissey and Port Mellon.  


People are advised to take care next to the coast. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message: High spring tides are expected to affect the foreshore this evening, 28/03/2021. Tides will be at their highest between 23:30 today, 28/03/2021, and 01:30 tomorrow, 29/03/2021. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times. However, conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land, roads and coastal paths at Fleetwood Docks and Marina, Fleetwood Marsh Nature Park, Barnaby's Sands, Burn Naze, Sower Carr, Hambleton, Stannah, Trunnah, Thornton, Skippool and Little Eccleston. The next high tide at 12:30 on 29/03/2021 is also expected to exceed the Flood Alert threshold. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near rivers. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 29/03/2021, or as the situation changes.

Large and powerful waves are expected to affect the foreshore as a result of high spring tides and strong winds.  Consequently, flooding of low lying coastal paths, roads and farmland is possible between 21:30 and 01:30 Sunday, 28/03/21.  Flooding is expected to affect low lying land, roads and coastal paths at Mossband Hall, Eden estuary, Burgh Marsh, Port Carlisle, Bowness-on-Solway, Wampool estuary, Waver estuary, Skinburness Marsh, Skinburness and Silloth.   

We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths and roads along the coastline. The high tide tomorrow lunchtime will also cross the Flood Alert threshold and will be updated tomorrow morning, Monday 29/03/2021, or as the situation changes.

Large and powerful waves are expected to affect the foreshore as a result of high spring tides and strong winds.  Consequently, flooding of low lying coastal paths, roads and farmland is possible between 21:00 and 01:00 Sunday, 28/03/21. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land, roads and coastal paths at West Shore Park, Biggar Bank Road, Tummerhill Marshes, Rampside and Roa Island.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences.
  
Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths and roads along the coastline.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Monday 29/03/2021, or as the situation changes.

Large and powerful waves are expected to affect the foreshore as a result of high spring tides and strong winds.  Consequently, flooding of low lying coastal paths, roads and farmland is possible between 21:00 and 01:00 Sunday, 28/03/21. Flooding is expected to affect low lying land, roads and coastal paths at Millom, Millom Marsh, Duddon Bridge, A595, Foxfield, Angerton Marsh, Kirkby-in-Furness and Askam-in-Furness.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences.
  
Please avoid using low lying coastal footpaths and roads along the coastline.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Monday 29/03/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
A large tidal surge is expected with possible overtopping and onshore flooding as a result of high water levels. The time and date of the first forecast high water is 07:30 on 29/03/2021. The forecast tide level is 7.36 m AOD. The forecast wind strength and direction is Force 4 in a south south west direction. The time and date of the second forecast high water is 20:00 on 29/03/2021. The forecast tide level is 7.37 m AOD. The forecast wind strength and direction is Force 3 in a south south west direction. There is a possibility of flooding for the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham, and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehamption Park, including Pill and Shirehampton.

Our operation teams are closing flood gates in the Pill and Shirehampton area. 
Be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. 
Please note all tide times are in local time and are using the 24 hour clock and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth.

The high tide is expected to be higher than usual as a result of exceptionally high tides.  Consequently flooding of low lying land, roads and farmland is possible from 01:00 tomorrow, 29/03/21.  We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land in the following places: 
Fiddlers Ferry between 01:00 and 01:45, with a peak of 6.34m
Eastford Road between 01:15 and 02:00, with a peak of 6.5m
And Arpley Bridge between 01:30 and 02:15, with a peak of 6.55m
It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge.   
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will issue flood warnings if necessary.  
Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation.  
Based on current forecast, the subsequent 2 high tides are also forecast to reach the flood alert threshold tomorrow 29/03/21. We will issue further alerts and update this message as necessary.

River levels have risen at the Killington river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property/roads and farmland is expected/possible between 20:30 today and 06:00 tomorrow, 29/03/21.  Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in Tebay, Sedbergh, Dent, Barbon, Kirkby Lonsdale and surrounding areas. High river levels are possible on the Rivers Lune, Rawthey, Clough and Dee and their tributaries.   
We expect river levels to remain main high until 06:00 on 29/03/21. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow morning, 29/03/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are forecast to rise at the Garstang Flood Control Structure river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property/roads and farmland is expected between 03:00 and 07:00 tomorrow, 29/03/2021.  Flooding is expected to affect low lying land and roads in Abbeystead, Dolphinholme, Galgate, Scorton, Garstang, Churchtown and Billsborrow. High river levels are possible on the Rivers Wyre, Conder, Calder and Brock, Barton Brook, Woodplumpton Brook and their tributaries.    
We expect river levels to rise, peaking 2.03 mtrs at 03:30 on 29/03/21 
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near rivers.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow morning, 29/03/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Greta at Keswick, Keswick Campsite, Rugby Club and Quinta
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Keswick Camp Site river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected.  Flooding is expected to affect low lying roads, residential, commercial properties and campsites in Keswick adjacent to the Rivers Greta and Derwent. Including Greta Park Rugby Football Ground, Keswick Campsite, Keswick School Sports Field, Keswick Show Field and Playing Field areas   
We expect river levels to remain high until later today 29/03/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow morning, 30/03/21, or as the situation changes.
